newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia mulls tier system for stockbrokers.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia mulls tier system for stockbrokers.

text.p: Malaysian stockbroking houses may be placed under a tiered system similar to that for financial institutions as part of efforts to liberalise the capital market, Business Times said on Tuesday.

It quoted Securities Commission chairman Munir Abdul Majid as saying that under a planned tiered system, stockbrokers who plan to opt for a wider scope of services will be allowed to do so if they met certain requirements.
"These qualifications could be based on capital, management capabilities and track record," Munir said in response to a question on the tiering of stockbrokers at a speech on the securities industry.
But he said the securities watchdog body has not decided on the type of tier system which would be implemented.

Malaysian banks, finance and insurance companies are placed under a two-tier system, with Tier-1 status granted to institutions which meet requirements on capital adequacy, asset quality, management efficiency, earnings performance and liquidity performance.
